title: Nuclear Terminology Glossary
text:
Automatic Actuation Logic
A system designed to initiate safety-related equipment operation without human intervention when specific conditions are met.


Bistables
Control devices that switch between on and off states.


Cold Shutdown (MODE 5)
A reactor operational mode where the coolant temperature is below 200°F (93°C) and the reactor is subcritical.


Condensate System
Recycles used steam back into water for reuse.


Control Board Instruments
Devices located in the control room of a power plant that are used to monitor and operate various equipment and systems.


Corrective Actions
Steps taken to fix problems and prevent them from happening again in the future.


Coincidence Logic
System requiring multiple conditions to be met for an action, like shutting down the reactor.


Counseling and Training
Providing guidance and education to personnel, ensuring staff understand their tasks and the importance of following procedures accurately.


Decay Heat
The heat produced by the radioactive decay of fission products after a nuclear reactor has been shut down.


Decay Heat Closed Cycle Cooling Water Pump
A pump that circulates cooling water to remove decay heat from a shutdown reactor.


Data Verification Process
A procedure for checking and confirming that recorded data is accurate and reliable.


Deaerator
Removes gases from water to prevent corrosion in the reactor.


Emergency Diesel Generator (EDG)
A backup generator that provides power during a loss of external power, ensuring safety systems remain operational.


Emergency Safeguards (ES) Bus
A critical power supply system for essential safety equipment, providing electricity to important safety systems during an emergency.


HPI (High Pressure Injection)
An emergency core cooling system that injects coolant into the reactor vessel under high pressure conditions.


Human Factors Evaluation
An assessment that looks at how people interact with their work environment and tasks to identify potential errors and difficulties. This helps to improve procedures and reduce mistakes.


Inattention to Detail
Failing to notice important details during tasks, which can lead to mistakes compromising safety and efficiency.


Lock Out
A safety procedure that ensures a system remains off, preventing accidental activation during maintenance or testing.


Loss of Power Start Signal
A signal indicating that the main power has been lost and backup systems should start, triggering emergency systems like diesel generators.


Missed Readings
Instances where required measurements or data recordings were not taken at the specified time.


Neutron Detector Channels
Devices that measure neutron levels to monitor reactor behavior.


Offsite Power Transformer
A transformer that connects the plant to the external power grid, allowing the plant to receive and send power to the grid.


Operator
A trained professional responsible for monitoring and controlling nuclear reactor operations.


Operator Error
Mistakes made by the staff who operate the plant’s equipment. This can include incorrect actions or failures to perform necessary actions.


Power Operated Relief Valves (PORVs)
Valves that release steam to control pressure.


Power Range Channels
Instruments that measure the reactor’s power output.


Procedure Revision
Updating and improving the set instructions for operations, correcting errors, improving clarity, and enhancing safety measures.


Protection System
Automatically shuts down the reactor if problems are detected.


Reactor Coolant System
A system that removes heat from the reactor core and transfers it to the steam generators, ensuring the reactor stays at a safe temperature.


Reactor Trip
An automatic shutdown of the reactor to prevent accidents.


Refueling Outage
A planned period during which a nuclear reactor is shut down for refueling and maintenance activities.


Safety Pump
A pump that is part of a nuclear power plant’s safety systems, designed to provide cooling in emergency situations.


Self-checking
A human performance tool used to focus an individual’s attention on the task at hand before taking action.


Shift Supervisor
The person responsible for overseeing operations and staff during a specific work shift.


STAR (Stop, Think, Act, Review)
A self-check process used in nuclear operations to reduce human error.


Steam Generator
A device that heats water to produce steam. This steam is then used to turn turbines, which generate electricity.


Surveillance Procedure
A set of instructions for performing tests to verify the operability of safety-related equipment.


Technical Specification Surveillance Interval Limits
Required time intervals for performing safety checks.


Trip Block Switch
A switch that prevents certain safety systems from being triggered during testing, avoiding unintended activation during maintenance.


Undervoltage Condition
A situation where the voltage drops below the required level, triggering safety systems to prevent damage or unsafe conditions.

title: Personnel Error During Surveillance Testing Causes Loss of Emergency Safeguards Bus
section: The Incident: A Timeline of Events
text:
The Incident: A Timeline of Events
On February 7, 1995, during the performance of a surveillance procedure at A Plant, a personnel error led to the loss of the “A” Emergency Safeguards (ES) bus. The reactor was operating at 100% power, generating 879 megawatts at the time of the incident.
The error occurred when a technician failed to position a “Trip Block” switch correctly. When the test pushbutton was pressed, an undervoltage condition was sensed, triggering an Emergency Diesel Generator (EDG) Loss of Power Start signal. This caused the “A” ES bus to strip and lock out the supply breakers. Fortunately, the associated EDG did not start since it was taken out of service for the surveillance.

title: Personnel Error During Surveillance Testing Causes Loss of Emergency Safeguards Bus
text:
What Was Missed?
The personnel error resulted in several critical issues:

Loss of Emergency Safeguards Bus: The “A” ES bus was de-energized, causing a temporary loss of power to critical systems.
Delayed Power Restoration: It took nine minutes to restore power to the “A” ES bus from the offsite power transformer.

title: Personnel Error During Surveillance Testing Causes Loss of Emergency Safeguards Bus
text:
Root Causes: Unraveling the Incident
The investigation revealed two primary causes:

Personnel Error: The technician’s inattention to detail led to the incorrect positioning of the “Trip Block” switch.
Inadequate Labeling and Communication: The switch identification was obscured by wiring, and there was a failure in communicating the completion of procedural steps.

title: Personnel Error During Surveillance Testing Causes Loss of Emergency Safeguards Bus
section: Assessing the Impact: Was Safety Compromised?
text:
Assessing the Impact: Was Safety Compromised?
Despite the loss of the “A” ES bus, the plant remained stable, with no significant changes in reactor coolant system pressure or temperature. The incident did not compromise public health and safety, but it highlighted procedural weaknesses.

title: Personnel Error During Surveillance Testing Causes Loss of Emergency Safeguards Bus
section: Corrective Actions: Strengthening Procedures and Supervision
text:
Corrective Actions: Strengthening Procedures and Supervision
In response to this incident, the plant implemented several key measures:

Counseling and Training: The maintenance crew was counseled, and the event was reviewed with all shop personnel to emphasize human error and event-free operations.
Procedure Revision: The surveillance procedure was revised to enhance clarity and prevent recurrence.
Improved Labeling: Labels were placed on the appropriate cabinet doors to ensure clear switch identification.

title: Personnel Error During Surveillance Testing Causes Loss of Emergency Safeguards Bus
text:
Key Lessons for Nuclear Operations
This incident offers valuable insights for the nuclear industry:

Attention to Detail: Even minor lapses in procedure can have significant impacts.
Thorough Supervision: Effective supervision and clear communication are essential for error prevention.
Procedural Improvements: Regular evaluation and enhancement of procedures can help prevent future incidents.

title: Personnel Error During Surveillance Testing Causes Loss of Emergency Safeguards Bus
text:
Conclusion: Vigilance in Every Detail
While this incident did not result in immediate safety concerns, it serves as a powerful reminder of the importance of meticulous attention to detail in nuclear operations. From the technicians performing tasks to the supervisors overseeing procedures, every role is crucial in maintaining the highest standards of safety.
As we reflect on this event, let’s remember that in nuclear safety, there are no small oversights. Every step, every procedure, and every communication contributes to the overall safety of the plant and the surrounding community. By learning from incidents like this and continuously improving our processes, we can work towards a future of enhanced nuclear safety and reliability.

title: Unexpected Pump Activation Highlights Human Error Risks
text:
What Happened? A Quick Overview
On a quiet summer morning, Nuclear Power Plant B in Region A experienced an unexpected event. During a routine monthly test, a safety pump suddenly activated, catching the control room team off guard. How did this happen, and what can we learn from it?



( Source: Wikimedia )

title: Unexpected Pump Activation Highlights Human Error Risks
text:
The Incident in Detail

Timeline of Events

Time: 10:18 AM
Location: Control room of Nuclear Power Plant B
Activity: Monthly automatic actuation logic test
Unexpected Outcome: Automatic start of a Decay Heat Closed Cycle Cooling Water Pump



What Went Wrong?
The root of the problem lay in a simple yet critical mistake. An operator placed the wrong switch in the “off” position. Specifically:

Correct Action: Turn off the HPI AUTO TEST GRP 3 switch
Actual Action: Turned off the “A” HPI AUTO TEST SELECT switch

This seemingly small error was enough to trigger the unexpected pump activation.

title: Unexpected Pump Activation Highlights Human Error Risks
section: Why Did It Happen? Digging Deeper
text:
Why Did It Happen? Digging Deeper

Root Causes Identified

Inadequate self-checking during complex tasks
Multiple distractions in the control room
Overly complex test procedure (145 pages!)
No formal pre-job briefing
Lack of a dedicated procedure reader
Failure to manage control room distractions
Perceived time pressure at shift end



The Human Factor: A Critical Element
This incident shines a spotlight on the crucial role of human factors in nuclear safety. Even in highly automated environments, human decision-making and actions remain pivotal.

title: Unexpected Pump Activation Highlights Human Error Risks
text:
Safety Impact: Assessing the Consequences
Fortunately, the impact of this incident was minimal:

Only one pump activated unexpectedly
No systems or safety functions were compromised
No equipment damage occurred

However, the potential for more serious consequences underscores the importance of addressing such incidents promptly and thoroughly.

title: Unexpected Pump Activation Highlights Human Error Risks
text:
Learning from Mistakes: Corrective Actions
In response to this event, the plant implemented several key measures:

Comprehensive discussion with shift personnel
Renewed emphasis on the STAR principle (Stop, Think, Act, Review)
Creation of a lessons-learned entry in the Operations Study Book
Assignment of dedicated procedure readers for complex tests

title: Unexpected Pump Activation Highlights Human Error Risks
text:
Key Lessons for Nuclear Safety
This incident offers valuable insights for the entire nuclear industry:

Self-checking is crucial: Always verify actions before execution.
Manage the work environment: Minimize distractions in critical areas.
Simplify complex procedures: Break down lengthy processes into manageable steps.
Prioritize communication: Ensure clear, effective teamwork at all times.

title: Unexpected Pump Activation Highlights Human Error Risks
section: Conclusion: Building a Stronger Safety Culture
text:
Conclusion: Building a Stronger Safety Culture
While this incident didn’t result in serious consequences, it serves as a vital reminder of the ongoing need for vigilance in nuclear operations. By focusing on human factors, improving procedures, and fostering a robust safety culture, we can work towards preventing similar incidents in the future.
Remember, in nuclear safety, there’s no such thing as a small oversight. Every action, every decision matters. Let’s learn from this experience and continue to strengthen our commitment to nuclear safety.

Root causes include operator error and inadequate shift supervision review.

title: Nuclear Plant Log Keeping Errors: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
section: The Incident: A Timeline of Oversights
text:
The Incident: A Timeline of Oversights
On February 4, 1986, a nuclear power plant licensee made a concerning discovery. During a routine supervisory log review, it came to light that several critical instrument channel operability checks had been missed on January 29, 1986. This oversight led to exceeding technical specification surveillance interval limits for eight control board instruments.

title: Nuclear Plant Log Keeping Errors: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
text:
What Was Missed?
The missed readings affected crucial steam generator instruments:

‘B’ and ‘C’ Steam Generator Pressure
‘B’ and ‘C’ Steam Generator Water Level
‘B’ and ‘C’ Feedwater Flow
‘B’ and ‘C’ Steamline Pressure

These instrument checks are vital for ensuring the safe operation of the nuclear power plant, particularly in monitoring the condition of the steam generators.

title: Nuclear Plant Log Keeping Errors: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
text:
Root Causes: Unraveling the Oversight
The investigation into this incident revealed two primary causes:

Operator Error: Mistakes made during the process of taking and recording log readings.
Inadequate Supervision: Insufficient review of logs by shift supervisors.

These findings underscore the importance of both individual responsibility and effective oversight in maintaining nuclear safety standards.

title: Nuclear Plant Log Keeping Errors: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
section: Assessing the Impact: Was Safety Compromised?
text:
Assessing the Impact: Was Safety Compromised?
Upon discovery of the missed readings, the licensee took immediate action:

They reviewed data recorded before and after the missed readings.
This review verified that the instrument channels had remained operable.
All instruments were found to be within technical specification tolerances.

While this outcome is reassuring, it doesn’t diminish the seriousness of the oversight. In nuclear safety, vigilance is paramount, and any lapse in procedure can potentially lead to more severe consequences.

title: Nuclear Plant Log Keeping Errors: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
section: Corrective Actions: Strengthening the Safety Culture
text:
Corrective Actions: Strengthening the Safety Culture
In response to this incident, the plant implemented several key measures:

Counseling for operators and shift supervision on the importance of accurate log keeping and thorough review.
A management review board inquiry into the event.
Human factors evaluation of the operating logs to improve usability and reduce error potential.
Involvement of personnel involved in the event in developing corrective actions.

These steps demonstrate a commitment to learning from mistakes and actively improving safety procedures.

title: Nuclear Plant Log Keeping Errors: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
text:
Key Lessons for Nuclear Operations
This incident offers valuable insights for the entire nuclear industry:

Accuracy is crucial: Even seemingly minor documentation errors can have significant implications.
Supervision matters: Thorough review processes are essential for catching and correcting errors.
Continuous improvement: Regular evaluation of procedures and logs can help prevent future oversights.
Involve the team: Engaging personnel in corrective actions can strengthen the overall safety culture.

title: Nuclear Plant Log Keeping Errors: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
text:
Conclusion: Vigilance in Every Detail
While this incident didn’t result in any immediate safety concerns, it serves as a powerful reminder of the importance of meticulous attention to detail in nuclear operations. From the operators recording data to the supervisors reviewing logs, every role plays a crucial part in maintaining the highest standards of safety.
As we reflect on this event, let’s remember that in nuclear safety, there are no small oversights. Every log entry, every review, and every procedure contributes to the overall safety of the plant and the surrounding community. By learning from incidents like this and continuously improving our processes, we can work towards a future of enhanced nuclear safety and reliability.

title: Reactor Trip During Nuclear Instrument Surveillance: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
section: The Incident: A Timeline of Events
text:
The Incident: A Timeline of Events
On May 31, 1986, at approximately 10:26 AM, a reactor trip occurred at a nuclear power plant. The reactor was operating at 100% power when the trip was initiated due to personnel error during operational testing of the power range neutron detector channels.
During a routine test of power range channel N-42, a technician inadvertently continued the test on channel N-41, which caused the reactor to trip as the protection system detected a false condition.

title: Reactor Trip During Nuclear Instrument Surveillance: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
text:
What Was Missed?
The reactor trip led to several critical issues:

Damage to the Condensate System: A water hammer event caused by a transient in the condensate system resulted in damage, delaying reactor restart.
Unmonitored Release: Steam release through secondary power operated relief valves (PORVs) due to steam generator tube leakage led to an unmonitored release to the atmosphere.

title: Reactor Trip During Nuclear Instrument Surveillance: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
text:
Root Causes: Unraveling the Incident
The investigation revealed two primary causes:

Personnel Error: The technician failed to follow the correct procedure, resulting in the reactor trip.
Inadequate Labeling and Procedures: Insufficient labeling of instrument drawers and inadequate test procedures contributed to the error.

title: Reactor Trip During Nuclear Instrument Surveillance: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
section: Assessing the Impact: Was Safety Compromised?
text:
Assessing the Impact: Was Safety Compromised?
Upon the reactor trip, the plant’s response was normal, with all safety systems functioning as designed. However, subsequent issues included:

Condensate System Damage: The water hammer event caused significant damage.
Unmonitored Release: The release to the atmosphere, though a small fraction of allowable limits, highlighted procedural weaknesses.

title: Reactor Trip During Nuclear Instrument Surveillance: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
section: Corrective Actions: Strengthening Procedures and Supervision
text:
Corrective Actions: Strengthening Procedures and Supervision
In response to this incident, the plant implemented several key measures:

Counseling and Training: Personnel involved were counseled and assigned to develop and present “Lessons Learned” training seminars.
Improved Labeling: Instrument drawers were re-labeled to reduce confusion.
Human Factors Review: The test procedure underwent a human factors review to improve usability and reduce error potential.
Engineering Modifications: Modifications to the condensate system were made to prevent future water hammer events.

title: Reactor Trip During Nuclear Instrument Surveillance: A Lesson in Operational Vigilance
text:
Key Lessons for Nuclear Operations
This incident offers valuable insights for the nuclear industry:

Attention to Detail: Even minor procedural lapses can have significant consequences.
Thorough Supervision: Effective supervision and review processes are essential for catching and correcting errors.
Procedural Improvements: Regular evaluation and improvement of procedures can help prevent future incidents.
Team Involvement: Engaging personnel in developing corrective actions strengthens the overall safety culture.
